options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much from this class! I learned a ton of new vocabulary, how to engage more naturally in conversation, grammatical principles, and more about the Deaf Community and Deaf Culture.

This course built upon the foundation of ASL 1. I learned American Sign Language signs and grammar, which I could both produce and respond to. We also learned about Deaf culture and the Deaf community, in both a historical sense and in terms of the Deaf community today.
I learned lots of new ASL vocabulary, grammatical concepts, and cultural aspects of the Deaf community.
Conversations in ASL, ASL vocab and grammer
an expanded vocabulary and understanding of grammar, especially classifiers
ASL grammar and vocabulary and also aspects of Deaf culture.
glossing & grammar
I expanded my knowledge of ASL vocabulary, grammar, and Deaf culture.
I greatly developed my signing skills, both through grammar and vocabulary. I also learned a lot about Deaf Culture.
Expanded ASL vocabulary and grammar skills; learned a lot about Deaf culture; lots of conversational practice. Topics covered include: weather, weekend plans, travel, personal references, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course has only strengths! I absolutely love this language, and the classroom model translated surprisingly well over Zoom. The work was very enjoyable (or, at the very least, educational), and I always looked forward to going to class.

This was a great course. The course was very well organized and went through a lot of content in a short period of time. I think a major strength is the constant practice of signs from the current unit and previous units. Also, there is a good balance between practicing sign production yourself and comprehending others' signs. The only weakness I can think of are due to the way Zoom restricts the signing space.

Strengths: The class is well organized, with clear expectations and structure. I enjoyed the flipped model of the class, because it allowed class time to be used for practicing new vocabulary learned in regular conversation. We received helpful feedback regularly that helped to advance our skills. No weaknesses!
The professor organizes the course very well and the canvas page is set up nicely so you don't miss assignments. She is also very understanding about assignments.

strengths: very well organized and easy to keep up with what assignments were due when, variety of different types of practice of vocabulary and grammar, engaging final project, incredible professor  
weaknesses: none
Dr. K is fantastic! Her class is so organized and she is probably the kindest prof at Yale.
The course was very organized, especially for being virtual. The topics were presented in a way that was easy to grasp and built on previous knowledge. I can't think of any weaknesses!
Dr. K did a great job of giving feedback, and I felt like I was always on track to improve.
Literally no weaknesses. SUCH an incredible and immersive learning experience with Dr.K. The sweetest professor ever.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Dr. K did an incredible job gearing this course towards learning during the pandemic. Our class time was always well-spent, and I think we benefitted from the virtual format in that sign memorization was done before class, through videos. That way, we could replay them as many times as we needed to learn signs, which is something that wouldn't have happened in person. The only thing I think this class lacked was due to the pandemic (and thus unavoidable): more conversation in person.

This course was transitioned as best as it could be to be in a virtual setting! Mostly, the robust Canvas page made it very easy to stay up to date on assignments and have an easy reference for old vocab. Also, breakout rooms made it easy to stay voice-off by using the chat, and practice signing in smaller groups.

Activities that were normally in person (such as games), were converted to virtual versions, but they were still very effective. It was harder to interact with people who weren't in the smaller groups we were assigned to at the beginning of the semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! I wholeheartedly love this course. If you are at all considering taking ASL, do it!!! Yale's ASL department is small, but the community is incredible and everyone in it loves the language and the culture that comes with the people who speak it.

Absolutely! I would especially recommend this course to people who are interested in/connected to the Deaf community and want to learn more. This was a very engaging and interesting course, and I could not recommend it more -- whether you are seeking to fulfill a language credit, or just take L1 to learn some ASL foundation.
I 10000% would recommend this course to any student interested in learning ASL as well as Deaf Culture.
Yes it is a great class! The material is fun and pretty easy to pick up on
definitely yes!
Yes! This is a perfect low-stress language course that you will also learn A LOT in. This class is voice off which takes a bit of adjustment. But it really helps facilitate learning!!
Yes
Yes! Not only does the class do an excellent job at effectively teaching the language, but it also teaches students about an important community that is often overlooked in America.

YES YES YES. Cannot recommend this class more. I don't know how different of an experience it will be without Dr.K as this is her last semester at Yale but this class made me fall even more love with American Sign Language and really made me feel like a more capable communicator and better signer.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Most of our homework assignments involved learning new ASL signs and other supplemental material through videos Dr. K had made and posted for us online.

This class included synchronous teaching, as well as asynchronous activities out of class. The class was flipped, meaning we would learn vocabulary out of class then use class time for practice and application.
videos for vocabulary
none
Dr. K hosted additional office hours and reviews outside of class.
Asynchronous work on days we do not have live class + nightly assignments.
